html:
The issue of whether free will can exist in a world where everything is predetermined is one fraught with difficulties, both linguistic, in terms of establishing the definitions of the two key terms in this question, and scientific, because to examine determinism is to attempt to break down causality. Here is where we insert TWO LINE BREAKS.

David Hume is often seen as one of the main proponents of compatibilism, or soft determinism, the doctrine which argues that there is something called free will which is not mutually exclusive to something called determinism. His argument for this is put forward in several ways, after this ONE LINE BREAK.
Firstly, he examines the notion of causality, and concludes that humans have a tendency to infer a connection between two events (i.e. say that one caused the other) when in fact no such connection exists, although certainly we see the constant and regular conjunction of similar events . Secondly, he provides an example of this, in that men throughout the ages have tended to ONE LINE BREAK AGAIN.
Then this final thing, TWO LINE BREAKS after.

And then Nothing.
text:
The issue of whether free will can exist in a world where everything is
predetermined is one fraught with difficulties, both linguistic, in terms
of establishing the definitions of the two key terms in this question, and
scientific, because to examine determinism is to attempt to break down
causality. Here is where we insert TWO LINE BREAKS.

David Hume is often seen as one of the main proponents of compatibilism, or
soft determinism, the doctrine which argues that there is something called
free will which is not mutually exclusive to something called determinism.
His argument for this is put forward in several ways, after this ONE LINE
BREAK.
Firstly, he examines the notion of causality, and concludes that humans
have a tendency to infer a connection between two events (i.e. say that one
caused the other) when in fact no such connection exists, although
certainly we see the constant and regular conjunction of similar events .
Secondly, he provides an example of this, in that men throughout the ages
have tended to ONE LINE BREAK AGAIN.
Then this final thing, TWO LINE BREAKS after.

And then Nothing.
